subject: RE: [junit] Including test cases with production code
msgSnippet: ... Definitely if source code is provided, including test cases make sense. I think we all agree now that within the context of end-user application
messageBody:
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Mike Clark [mailto:mike@...]
> Sent: Friday, July 06, 2001 2:41 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] Including test cases with production code
>
>
> Vladimir Bossicard wrote:
>
> >>>Can someone explain why someone (i.e. a customer) would want to clutter
> >>>their storage or bandwith with test cases?
> >>>
> >>In general, if the customer is able to modify the application source
> >>code, then the test cases carry their weight. Examples include open
> >>source applications or products where the source code is the primary
> >>deliverable (e.g. frameworks).
> >>
> >
> > I think that we are talking about two different products: the
> final application (a jar in the Java world) and the development
> environment.
> > The tests code is part of the source code but not part of the
> final application.
> > You always can keep the tests in the cvs tree or a separate
> package for download. If the customer has the knowledge to
> modify the code, he certainly know how to get code from a cvs tree :-)
> >
> > -Vladimir
> >
>
>
> I'm specifically referring to products where the source code is part and
> parcel of the product or the product provides a Java API. It's not
> always necessary to ship all of the test cases, but relevant test cases
> that document and validate the use of the product should easily make up
> for their storage and bandwidth penalties.
>
> Mike
> --
> Mike Clark
> Clarkware Consulting, Inc.
> Custom Software Architecture, Design,
> Development, and Performance Consulting
> http://www.clarkware.com

Definitely if source code is provided, including test cases make sense. I
think we all agree now that within the context of end-user application
deployment, it doesn't make sense to include test cases, except for special
diagnostic circumstances. If a product deliverable includes source code, or
is a framework that provides a set of Java APIs, then a set of test cases is
invaluable for documenting and validating product usage.
